Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They need to be on time for a scheduled court session that impacts the client’s case
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with a reminder: “Court session, 10:00 AM.” My heart thudded. At the same time, my mother’s voice echoed from the living room, “Don’t forget, you’re leading the family ceremony this morning. It means so much to your grandmother.” I could see the expectant faces of my family, counting on me to honor our traditions, to be the daughter who keeps our values alive. But my mind kept drifting to my client, whose future depended on my presence in court. As an advocate, punctuality wasn’t just a courtesy—it was a duty. Missing the session could jeopardize everything I’d worked for on their behalf. The weight of both worlds pressed on my chest. I wanted to be the devoted daughter, the reliable advocate. But the clock was ticking, and I knew I couldn’t be in two places at once. My hands trembled as I tried to steady my breath, torn between the pull of family and the call of justice, knowing that whatever I chose, something precious would be left behind.
